questions.text: A mother with a newborn is worried for her child as the newborn hasn't passed the meconium till after 6 hours of birth. How much maximum time should she wait for the to pass out!
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 48 hours Ninety-nine percent of healthy term newborns should pass meconium within 24 hours, and all term newborns should pass meconium within 48 hours. If delayed passage of meconium (beyond 48 hours) is encountered, the practitioner should aggressively consider important causes, including Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A neonate who was just born, was found to have a heart rate of 120/min with weak and irregular respiratory darts He had a pink body with blue extremities, partially flexed and he grimaced on stimulation by catheter. What is the APGAR score for this baby
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) heart rate 120/min – 2 Weak and irregular respiratory efforts – 1 Peripheral cyanosis (blue extremeties) – 1 Patially flexed limbs – 1 Grimace – 1 APGAR Score = 6

questions.text: Vitamin K is given at birth to prevent the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) At birth baby is deficient in Vit K and its deficiency can cause hemorrhagic disease of newborn Therefore Vit K supplementations are given to newborns in hospitals after birth. Babies delivered at home and which are on exclusive breast feeds tends to develop hemorrhagic ds of newborn in 2-7 days after birth.

questions.text: Infant of diabetic mother is at risk of development of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Infants of diabetic mother have high level of insulin in their intra uterine life. After birth this increased levels of insulin can cause hypoglycemia in them. Insulin stimulates erythropoietin hormone therefore these babies have polycythemia. Insulin also cause LEFT LAZY COLON SYNDROME therefore they have history of delayed passage of meconium.

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes is first to appear in a child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Question is asking which reflex is first to appear, not which reflex is fully developed first. Sequence in which reflexes appear is- (PMR) Palmer grasp refex- 28 wk Moro’s reflex- 28-32 wk Rooting reflex- 32-34 wk

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation when should chest compression be started?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chest compressions are started when Heart Rate is <60/min i.e Severe Bradycardia Ratio of chest compressions to PPV is 3:1 in every 2 sec Compressions are given on lower 1/3rd of sternum and compressions are 1/3rd of antero-posterior diameter of chest.

questions.text: Oral vitamin A dosage in 2-year-old malnourished child weighing 8 kg.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) vit A is also known as ANTI INFECTIVE Vitamin 6 mnth- 1yr = 1 lakh IU of vit A given >1yr = 2 lakh IU of vit A given >1yr but 1yr and >= 8 kg = 2 lakh IU given If signs of vit A deficiency present and child has history of Measles = 3 doses of Vit A are given on 1,2,14 days

questions.text: A child is having growth retardation and was on exclusive breast milk until 3 years of age. Child is dull and lethargic. Pitting Edema is present on examination. Diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Growth retardation, pitting edema, dull and lethargic child points towards Kwashiorkor Marasmus is alert and active child not a lethargy child Hypothyroidism has myxedema not pitting edema

questions.text: By WHO reference child’s height for age < 2 SD is called _______________
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stunting A child whose height-for-age is less than ?2 SD is considered stunted, because the chances of the child's height being normal are less than 3 percent. A child whose weight-for-age is less than ?2 SD is considered underweight, and one whose weight-for-height is less than ?2 SD is deemed wasted.

questions.text: A child came for regular check-up in OPD. His growth chart shows that weight of the child is between 85th – 95th percentile. Comment on child status?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) According to WHO criteria 1. Underweight (95th percentile) So answer is overweight

questions.text: Picture of a child, edematous, pot belly. The child is suffering from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sparse hair, less pigmented, round moon like facies, pott belly seen. Therefore most likely answer is Kwashiorkor

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency with generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Which drug should be given first to control his symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) First line drug in epilepsy are 1. midazolam (i.m) or 2. lorazepam (i.v) or 3. diazepam (i.v) if these are not available Rectal diazepam or intranasal diazepam can be given.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with recurrent staring episodes where he stopped blinking for 20 seconds. Which of the following drug would you like to give for treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) it’s a case of Absence seizure. Drugs used in absence seizures are 1. Ethosuximide (DOC) 2. Sodium valproate 3. Lamortigine

questions.text: In a child presenting with febrile seizures, first line drug to control seizures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) First line drug used to control seizure is Midazolam In Simple febrile seizure – no prophylaxis given In Complex Febrile Seizure – intermittent prophylaxis given with diazepam/ clonazepam /clobazam

questions.text: A child has a large head, large tongue and both e testicles are also large in sine. The child also shows features of autism spectrum disorder. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Macrocephaly, macroglossia, large mandible, macro orchidism + features of autism is characteristic of Fragile X syndrome. CGG repeats present

questions.text: A child with developmental delay shows the karyotype depicted below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 21 Trisomy is Down Syndrome Arrow marked chromosome is 21 Trisomy is Down Syndrome. Down syndrome is a chromosome disorder caused by an extra chromosome 21 that results in intellectual disability and physical abnormalities. People with Down syndrome may have these physical characteristics: a small chin, epicanthic folds, low muscle tone, a flat nasal bridge, a single crease of the palm, and a protruding tongue. A protruding tongue is caused by low tone and weak facial muscles, and often corrected with myofunctional exercises.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency unit after he is pushed down while playing. After falling on his knees, he developed swelling and bruising of his left knee. History revealed that his maternal uncle also has a similar presentation. What could be the probable mode of inheritance of this child's condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) X linked recessive History of bleeding in joint indicate towards Hemophilia A, B. Joint bleeds are the main cause of chronic pain and disability in people with severe hemophilia.Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive hereditary disorder that classically affects males due to the presence of only one X chromosome in males.

questions.text: A couple is trying to have a child for past 2 years, after multiple unsuccessful trials they went for respective examination. Investigation of female came out to be absolutely normal but male shows presence of gynecomastia, small testis and scanty pubic hairs. He had a history of antisocial behaviour during school days. Most probably he has:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Atrophic testis during puberty → decreased testosterone → scanty pubic hair, small testis and increased estrogen responsible for gynecomastia Only symptom in case of klinefelter syndrome in childhood is antisocial behavior

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, TOF, thymic hypoplasia and microdeletion in chromosome 22q11.2?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DiGeorge Syndrome i.e Velocardiofacial syndrome is defect of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch which leads to defect in development of parathyroid and thymus glands. Defective development of Parathyroid gland causes hypocalcemia

questions.text: Mutation in NPHS 1 gene causes which disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Congenital nephrotic syndrome- 1.NPHS 1 gene codes for NEPHRIN protein. Mutation of which leads to Finnish type Nephrotic Syndrome. 2.NPHS-2 gene codes for PODOCIN Protein 3. wilms tm 1 gene 4. LAMB2- Beta 2 laminin gene defect

questions.text: Henoch Schonlein purpura commonly involves which age group?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HSP – M/C vasculitis in children of 3-10 yrs of age Involvement of skin, joints,GIT, kidney

questions.text: A 7-year- old female child presents with crampy abdominal pain and rash mainly on the back of her leg, buttocks as well as on the extensor surface of his forearm. Laboratory analysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rash present in lower limbs, gluteal reg. on extensor surface of forearm + git involvement + renal involvement indicates towards Henoch Schoenlein Purpura. Also age group is between 3-10 yrs

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with periorbital edema and pedal edema + ascites. Electron microscopy shows effacement of podocytes. Identify the condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peri orbital edema, pedal edema, ascites + EM showing Effacement of Podocytes indicate towards MINIMAL CHANGE DISEASE. On light microscopy- glomerulus appears normal m/c cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease.

choices.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics and follow up after 2 weeks
Give first dose ampicillin and gentamicin and refer urgently to hospital
Reassure mother that it is just cough and cold
Do nothing, refer the baby to tertiary care center

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has respiratory rate of 58/minute and chest indrawing. The baby has not been able to feedfor last 10 hrs. What is the best management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2-12 mnth – respiratory rate >50/min = fast breathing, which favours pneumonia Presence of Lethargic child , SAMz History of convulsions, decreased level of consciousness, persistent vomitting child not able to take feeds are dangerous signs indicating towards SEVERE PNEUMONIA or Very severe disease. Next best mgt is give first dose of ampicillin and gentamicin and refer urgently

questions.text: A one and half year-old child presents with single episode of wheeze and breathing difficulty. CXR is done and it shows bilateral hyperinflation. Which organism is most commonly responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diagnosis – Bronchiolitis occurs in children of 1-6 mnths of age. Can also be seen upto 2 yrs of life. m/c cause of bronchiolitis is Respiratory syncytial virus

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing. On examination respiratory rate=60/ min, child is irritable but mother is able to feed the child. There is no stridor, no chest indrawing, no convulsions. (Most Recent Question Dec 2019) Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Danger signs – SAM, History of convulsions, lethargic child, decreased level of consciousness, persistent vomiting, not able to feed Since pt. does not have any danger signs so it is a simple case of pneumonia

questions.text: Which of the following clinical presentation is correct for a child with pneumonia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fast breathing is in 2-12 months = respiratory rate > 50/min In 12-59 months = respiratory rate is >40/min

choices.text: Severe pneumonia: give antibiotics and refer urgently
Pneumonia, oral antibiotics and come back after 5 days
Give only antipyretic and send home

questions.text: A 2-year-old child who presented with fever had a RR of 36/min and chest indrawing, What is the diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Only presence of chest indrawings also suggest Pneumonia, oral antibiotics given for 5 days and follow up after 2 days.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to your PHC with complaints of diarrhea and is unable to take feeds or ORS. His weight is 17 kg. What is the amount of maintenance fluid required in 24 hours?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) upto 10 kg-100ml/kg 11-20 kg -50ml/kg >20kg- 20ml/kg Maintenance fluid req = 10*100 + 7*50 = 1350 ml

choices.text: Give IV fluids for 4 hours followed by ORS

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy was brought with a history of 18 episodes of loose stools and 2 episodes of vomiting. The child is irritable, but can drink eagerly. What is the best way to manage this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Minimal dehydration – alert child Some dehydration – irritable child, thirsty = give ors only Severe dehydration – lethargic child

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is present with short stature. On biochemical examination, growth hormone levels are elevated with very low levels of IGF-1. Which of the following could be the possible defect in this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Growth hormone ?acts on growth hormone receptor ? produces IGF-1 which is bounded by IGF-1 Binding protein 3 ? then it binds to IGF-1 Receptor Its given that growth hormone levels are elevated that means GH is unable to bind to GH Receptor. So, its GH Receptor deficiency also known as Laron’s Dwarfism

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with yellowish discoloration of skin and hypotonia. On examination, the baby also has large protruded tongue and umbilical hernia. Which of the following would be initial step in the evaluation of his clinical condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Jaundice, hypotonia, macroglossia(myxedema), umbilical hernia all indicate towards congenital hypothyroidism. Serum TSH Levels should be done as initial steps in evaluation. Approx.. 1/3 of thyroxin hormone is transferred from mother to child therefore the child presents 3 week late

questions.text: A newborn is found to have ambiguous genitalia. Work up shows high 17 hydroxyprogesterone, progesterone and DHEAS levels. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Screening test for 21 hydroxylase deficiency – 17OH progesterone Screening test for 11 hydroxylase deficiency – 11 deoxycortisol level

questions.text: In a child with short stature bone age is corresponding to the chronological age. Child height is comparable with parent height records. What is likely condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bone age = chronological age in Familial short stature In remaining all 3 bone age <chronological age

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with hematemesis and was found to have splenomegaly, on examination. There was a past history of exchange transfusion in this child for neonatal jaundice What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Past history of exchange transfusion indicates towards umbilical vein catheterization. Best probabl diagnosis is Portal vein Thrombosis.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presented with hemarthrosis of left knee after a history of fall. Deficiency of which factor can lead to the following condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hemearthrosis occurs in Factor VIII deficiency i.e hemophilia

questions.text: A 11 year old child is found to be anemic with previous history of multiple blood transfusions, Lab values reveal: Hb-8 g/dLV MCV-70 fLy MCH.MCHC-normal Blood smear - microcytic, hypochromic RBCs Which of the following investigation should be done next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Low hemoglobin, low MCV, microcytic and hypochromic RBC in peripheral smear and history of multiple blood transfusion indicates towards Thalassemia. So to diagnose thalassemia next investigation done should be Hb Electrophoresis.

questions.text: A child presents with redness of eyes, fever, backache and generalized rash as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All these symptoms indicate towards Measles

questions.text: A child presents with different types of rashes, including papules, vesicles and pustules involving the whole body and these rashes are present all at the same time and appearance of rash is associated with the onset of fever. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiple types of rashes present at same time indicates towards Chicken Pox. Also in chicken pox appearance of rash is associated with onset of fever.

questions.text: What is the organism responsible for this rash seen in an otherwise well child, who also had oral ulcers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In simultaneous involvement of hand foot and mouth indicates that it is hand foot and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with complaints of hematuria with history of sore throat 2 weeks .On assessment, no fever and cola colored urine was noted. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) History of respiratory infection + hematuria 1. 1-2 days back with normal serum C3 Levels – diagnosis is IgA nephropathy 2. 1-2 weeks back with low serum C3 Levels – diagnosis is PSGN

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ringer’s lactate with 5% dextrose If a child with SAM is lethargic or unconscious with cold extremities plus decreased capillary refill or weak fast pulse, it is said to be in shock. Intravenous resuscitation in SAM is only recommended in those with shock. IV fluids that can be used in children are-RL with 5% dextrose and Half normal saline with 5% dextrose.

questions.text: How much oxygen is given to a term infant with respiratory distress during resuscitation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 21% Resuscitation in term infants is done using 21% oxygen or room air. Resuscitation in preterm infants can be initiated with slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21-30%) and titrated as needed.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Galactosemia in infant Classic galactosemia is due to complete deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase leading to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate. Breast milk contains galactose hence these infants should not be fed breast milk.

questions.text: An 8 year old child presented with sudden onset high-grade fever, seizures, and loss of consciousness. On examination, the child had anemia, hypoglycemia and no neurological deficits. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cerebral malaria This scenario depicts a case of cerebral malaria due to a severe complicated falciparum infection. Severe complicated malaria is caused by Plasmodium falciparum and is characterised by jaundice, severe anaemia, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse renal failure and cerebral malaria.

questions.text: A child who has overdosed on iron tablets comes with nausea and abdominal pain. What is the antidote for this toxicity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Deferoxamine Deferoxamine, a potent iron-chelating compound, can be given intravenously to bind iron that has already been absorbed and to promote its excretion in urine and faeces.

questions.text: Gonadal growth corresponds with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Skeletal system Gonadal growth corresponds with a growth spurt during puberty that results in somatic or skeletal growth. Gonadal growth is dormant during childhood and becomes prominent during puberty. Skeletal growth is a continuous process that is steady until the pubertal growth spurt during which it accelerates.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with a history of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress. An xray of the neonate is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Esophageal atresia with trachea-esophageal fistula The given symptoms of frothiness and respiratory distress and an Xray showing a nasogastric tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas are suggestive of esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

questions.text: A teenager was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of delayed puberty and secondary sexual development. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 45 XO

questions.text: Feature of turner syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Webbed neck

questions.text: Child can grasp object with one hand and transfer it to other hand. Age of child is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A. The ability to grasp an object with one hand and transfer it to the other hand is a developmental milestone that typically occurs around 6 months of age. 6 months (A): Around 6 months, infants refine their voluntary grasping (ulnar-palmar grasp). They begin to actively reach for objects, grasp them, and can intentionally transfer an object from one hand to the other. This shows developing hand-eye coordination and fine motor skills. 9 months (B): By 9 months, infants have more refined pincer grasps (using thumb and forefinger) and can manipulate objects more skillfully, often banging them together or putting them in containers. Object transfer is well-established by this age. 3 months (C): At this age, infants are typically developing their ability to swipe at objects and may briefly hold a rattle, but coordinated grasping and transferring objects between hands is not yet developed. Their grasp is often reflexive. 12 months (D): At 12 months, toddlers are typically developing more complex fine motor skills, such as stacking blocks, pointing, and feeding themselves. Object transfer is a much earlier milestone.

questions.text: Stranger anxiety appears at age
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6m

questions.text: Indication of epinephrine in neonatal resuscitations
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 60 bpm Epinephrine is indicated in neonatal resuscitation if the heart rate remains less than 60 beats per minute after 30 seconds of effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV) and chest compressions. This is the threshold for administering epinephrine in neonates to improve heart rate and circulation.

questions.text: Color in imnci for some dehydration
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Yellow

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia would not be seen beyond after
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 2 years

questions.text: Child with scalp swelling at birth
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Caput succedaneum is the most common cause of scalp swelling in newborns. It is a serosanguinous, subcutaneous, extraperiosteal fluid collection that occurs due to pressure from the birth canal during delivery. A key feature is that caput crosses suture lines because it lies above the periosteum. It is soft, pits on pressure, and is usually present immediately at birth. It resolves spontaneously within a few days and typically does not require treatment. A. Subgaleal haemorrhage Why it's incorrect: This is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition due to bleeding into the subaponeurotic space. It can cross suture lines, but it is deeper and more extensive than caput succedaneum. It often appears as a diffuse, fluctuant mass and may expand rapidly, leading to significant blood loss. While it also presents with swelling, it is less common than caput succedaneum and is more dangerous. B. Cephalhematoma Why it's incorrect: Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage, meaning it is located under the periosteum, which restricts it to one bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling usually appears hours after birth, not immediately, and may take weeks to resolve. Though common, its key distinction is that it is firm, well-defined, and limited to one bone, unlike the soft, diffuse swelling of caput. D. Meningocele Why it's incorrect: A meningocele is a neural tube defect involving the protrusion of the meninges through a spinal defect, usually along the midline of the back, not the scalp. It does not present as diffuse scalp swelling and is associated with other spinal or neurological findings. It is not a differential diagnosis for common scalp swellings present at birth due to delivery trauma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CGD • CGD: Caused by defective NADPH oxidase in phagocytes ? impaired killing of catalase-positive organisms. Patients present with recurrent infections, especially abscesses and granuloma formation. • SCID: Presents earlier, with severe infections of all types (viral, bacterial, fungal), failure to thrive, and lymphopenia. • Sialyl Lewis X: A carbohydrate structure required for leukocyte rolling; a deficiency is not a standalone disease. • LAD: Also presents with recurrent infections, especially with delayed umbilical cord separation and lack of pus formation due to impaired neutrophil migration.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: 1 lakh IU every 6 months till 5 years of age
1 lakh IU every 6 months till 4 years of age
2 lakh IU every 6 months till 5 years of age
2 lakh IU every 6 months till 4 years of age

questions.text: Dose of vitamin A given in child age 1 - 8 years
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Child came in OPD with history of recurrent infection. On physical examination height for age is less than expected. Child is not getting adequate feeds. Such child is having
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: In severe acute malnourished child there is dehydration present. Intravenous fluid of choice is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea and alopecia is associated with deficiency of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Pregnant female diagnosed as thalassemia carrier and her husband is also have thalassemia trait. Chances of thalassemia major in next generation is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When both the pregnant female and her husband are carriers of thalassemia (also known as having thalassemia trait), they are both heterozygous for the thalassemia gene. Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive disorder, meaning that a child must inherit two copies of the abnormal gene (one from each parent) to express the severe form of the disease, thalassemia major. Using basic Mendelian genetics, if we represent the normal gene as 'A' and the thalassemia gene as 'a', both parents have the genotype 'Aa'. A Punnett square of 'Aa' x 'Aa' yields the following probabilities for their offspring: AA (normal) - 25%, Aa (carrier) - 50%, and aa (thalassemia major) - 25%. Therefore, the chance of their child having thalassemia major is A. 25%. Incorrect options: B. 50% is incorrect. This percentage represents the probability that the child will also be a carrier of the thalassemia trait, inheriting one normal and one abnormal gene, but not the severe form of the disease. C. 75% is incorrect. This percentage would be the combined probability of the child being either unaffected (normal, AA) or a carrier (Aa), and does not specifically represent the chance of inheriting thalassemia major. D. 100% is incorrect. A 100% chance of thalassemia major would only occur if both parents had thalassemia major (genotype 'aa'), or if one parent had thalassemia major ('aa') and the other was a carrier ('Aa'), which would result in all offspring being either affected or carriers. Since both parents are only carriers, there is a clear probability for the child to be normal or a carrier.

questions.text: For antenatal screening for Downs syndrome quadruple test is done in which trimester
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2nd trimester.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 60ml/kg

questions.text: Child celiac disease can eat which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

Increased lymphocyte count, high sugar, high protein
Increased neutrophils, low sugar, high protein

questions.text: Child has history of not taking feeds properly and is irritable. On examination neck rigidity is present. There is history of sister taking treatment for tuberculosis. On CSF examination, likely finding is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Increased lymphocyte count, low sugar, high protein
